misconceptions.name: Reads coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 and reads four doubles, computing a geometric distance, instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this task by reading two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) from the user and using them for my calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read exactly one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, e.g., with `int grade = input.nextInt();`, after prompting with something like `Enter grade:`.
symptoms: Prompts say "Enter x1 and y1" and "Enter x2 and y2" instead of asking for a grade.
Four double variables (x1, y1, x2, y2) are read instead of a single grade variable.
There is no variable representing a grade value.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented or submitted a solution for a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator task, so all input handling is aligned with the wrong specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate prompts and variables with a single prompt and variable for the grade, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every input-related line uses coordinate-style prompts and variables; there is no mention of a grade anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: The program reads four doubles named x1, y1, x2, y2 with coordinate-style prompts instead of reading a single numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to classify grade as A or B
misconceptions.description: The program does not include any Boolean range checks or if/else logic to determine whether a numeric grade is in the A (90–100) or B (80–89) ranges; instead, it computes the distance between two points.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to compute and print the distance between two points; I don’t need to check numeric ranges or output letter categories.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to check whether the single grade value falls within 90–100 (A) or 80–89 (B), using correct Boolean expressions for those ranges.
symptoms: No if, else-if, or else statements appear anywhere in main.
No Boolean expressions involving a grade or comparing a value to 80 or 90.
Only arithmetic and a call to Math.sqrt are used; no branching based on input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented a distance calculator instead of a grade calculator, they never introduced any conditional logic to classify grades into letter ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a single grade, add an if/else-if chain, such as `if (grade >= 90) {...} else if (grade >= 80) {...}` to correctly identify A and B ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire method body is visible and contains no conditional statements or grade-related Boolean checks.

evidence.note: Main method performs arithmetic and prints a distance; it contains no if/else statements or range checks for grades A or B.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to classify grade as C or D
misconceptions.description: The code lacks any Boolean expressions or conditional branches that would check whether a grade falls in the C (70–79) or D (60–69) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I do not need to distinguish between different numeric ranges; computing a single numeric result (distance) is sufficient.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade calculator must further test the grade for middle ranges, e.g., `else if (grade >= 70) { // C }` and `else if (grade >= 60) { // D }`, so that each numeric range maps to its proper letter.
symptoms: No variables or comparisons relating to 60 or 70 appear in the code.
There is no else-if chain handling middle grade ranges.
The program never branches based on value intervals; it performs a straight-line distance calculation.
misconceptions.root_cause: By solving the wrong problem (distance instead of grading), the student omitted all conditional checks for intermediate grade ranges C and D.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if/else-if chain after handling A and B to include checks for `grade >= 70` (C) and `grade >= 60` (D).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no grade-related variables or conditional checks in the program, so it cannot implement C and D ranges.

evidence.note: This part of the code shows straight-line numeric computation and output with no branching, confirming there are no C or D range checks.

misconceptions.name: No default or else case for failing grades (F)
misconceptions.description: The program never considers what should happen when a grade is below 60; there is no default or else branch because there is no grade or conditional logic at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: Every possible input simply contributes to the distance formula; there is no need for a catch-all category like F.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After testing for A, B, C, and D ranges, the program should use an `else` branch to catch all other numeric grades (below 60) and classify them as F.
symptoms: No `else` branch appears anywhere in the code.
There is no handling for values outside any specified grade range, because no ranges are defined.
The program has a single fixed behavior (compute distance) regardless of input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Since the entire algorithm is for distance computation, the student did not implement a grade classification tree or a final else for F.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Once A–D are handled with if/else-if, add a final `else` that prints `Letter grade: F` to cover all remaining cases.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Reviewing the full method confirms there is no decision structure at all, so there cannot be an else for F.

evidence.note: The complete main method has no if/else structure and therefore no default case to represent F.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance text instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a message about the distance between two points and never outputs a letter grade (A–F) corresponding to a numeric grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The required output is the numeric distance between the two points, printed with a descriptive message.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required output is a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) that matches the numeric grade’s range, e.g., `System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter);`.
symptoms: The only printed line is "The distance of the two points is " followed by a double value.
There is no string "Letter grade" or any of the letters A, B, C, D, F in the output.
No variable or logic corresponds to a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the implemented algorithm is for distance calculation, the final output describes a distance instead of a letter grade derived from grade ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a `char` or `String` variable for the letter grade and, after the conditional checks, print it with a message like `Letter grade: B`.
related_concepts: Testing program output against the problem specification
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only output statement clearly describes distance, and there is no alternative or conditional output.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output refers only to distance and has no mention of letter grades or the phrase "Letter grade:" as specified in the problem.

misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the submitted code fulfills the requirements of Q3, or they have submitted the wrong file for this assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt for a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade
Code implements the mathematical distance formula (Math.sqrt)
Absence of any conditional statements or grade ranges check
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the assignment scope or file submission error.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please locate and submit the correct file that implements the logic for the Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements the distance formula and prompts for four coordinates explicitly, confirming it is a solution to a different geometry problem.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different problem solved.
The user is prompted for and reads four coordinates, not a single grade input.
The code calculates distance using the Euclidean distance formula instead of applying grading logic.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the required grade calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the assignment, submitted the wrong file, or reused code from a different problem without checking the requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of grade
Program reads 4 double values instead of 1 numeric grade
Program calculates distance instead of determining letter grade
Output shows distance formula result instead of letter grade
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not related to grades

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the Q3 problem statement and sample run carefully. Verify that your code prompts for 'Enter grade:', reads one value, and outputs 'Letter grade: [A-F]'. Implement the grading logic using if/else-if/else statements with the specified ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code solves a completely different problem. There is no ambiguity here; the code must be entirely rewritten to solve the correct problem.

evidence.snippet:

        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem (distance formula) instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program calculates the distance between two points instead of reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges (A–F). There is no logic related to grade ranges or letter-grade output, so the solution does not address the stated problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional statements to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
No conditional (if/else) logic exists for grade ranges.
Output text reports a distance value rather than a letter grade such as A, B, C, D, or F.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment prompt or reuse of code from a different exercise (distance-between-points) rather than implementing the required grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the program around a single numeric grade input. Replace the distance-formula logic with an if/else-if/else chain that checks the grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and prints the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Using if/else-if/else chains for range checks
Program output design to match requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every prompt, variable, and computation in the program refers to coordinates and distance; there is no mention of grades or letters, indicating the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: All logic is for reading two points and computing their distance; there is no grade input, no conditional ranges, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect input design for required single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading a single numeric grade, the program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) using hasNextDouble with a default of 0.0 when input is not a double. This does not match the requirement to read one numeric grade in the range 0–100 and assumes a completely different input format.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe the program should prompt for two coordinate pairs and that using hasNextDouble with a fallback of 0.0 is an acceptable way to handle input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt once for a grade, then read that numeric grade (e.g., using input.nextInt() or input.nextDouble()) and assume valid input unless the assignment specifies validation. The input format should be a single value, not multiple coordinates.
symptoms: Prompts request x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade.
Four separate numeric reads are performed instead of one.
Use of hasNextDouble() with default 0.0 silently converts invalid input to 0.0, which is not part of the specification.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the required input specification and possible confusion between numeric input for different problems (grades vs. coordinates).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompts and input code to read exactly one numeric grade (e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();`). Do not use hasNextDouble with arbitrary defaults unless the assignment explicitly asks for validation behavior.
related_concepts: Using Scanner to read numeric input
Designing prompts to match problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The input section clearly targets coordinates and uses four reads; nothing in the code suggests awareness of the single-grade input required by the problem.

evidence.note: Prompts and Scanner usage are for four double values representing two points, not one numeric grade from 0 to 100.
